the pewanalytics stats module¶

Statistics utilities for weighting, clustering, dimensionality reduction, and inter-rater reliability

Stats Utilities¶

pewanalytics.stats.compute_boolean_column_proportions(df, columns)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • df – data frame
  • columns – list of strings
Returns:

proportions, list of bools

Parameters:
  • df – data frame
  • column – list of strings
  • weight_col – string
Returns:

dict of column and (average and std)

Parameters:
  • series – Pandas Series
  • percentile – float

Clustering¶

pewanalytics.stats.clustering.compute_hdbscan_clusters(features, min_cluster_size=100, min_samples=1)[source]¶

Uses HDBSCAN clustering to automatically identify the best number of clusters and map each unit to one. Rows are the units, and columns are features. Returns a series with the cluster labels for each row.

Parameters:
  • features – TF-IDF sparse matrix or a Pandas DataFrame
  • min_cluster_size – int - minimum number of documents/units that can exist in a cluster.
  • min_samples – Minimum number of samples to draw (see HDBSCAN documentation for more)
Returns:

Series with the cluster ID that each row belongs to
pewanalytics.stats.clustering.compute_kmeans_clusters(features, k=10, return_score=False)[source]¶

Uses KMeans from sklearn

Parameters:
  • features – TF-IDF sparse matrix or pandas DataFrame
  • k –
Returns:

Series

Dimensionality Reduction¶

pewanalytics.stats.dimensionality_reduction.correspondence_analysis(edges, n=1)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • edges – edges is a dataframe of NxN where both the rows and columns are “nodes” and the values are some sort of closeness/similarity measure (so you could use a cosine similarity matrix if youre doing text)
  • n – Number of dimensions you want
Returns:
pewanalytics.stats.dimensionality_reduction.get_lsa(features, feature_names=None, k=20)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • features – A dataframe or sparse matrix with rows are documents and columns are features
  • feature_names – An optional list of feature names (for sparse matrices)
  • k – Number of dimensions to extract
Returns:

A tuple of two dataframes, (features x components, documents x components)
pewanalytics.stats.dimensionality_reduction.get_pca(features, feature_names=None, k=20)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • features – A dataframe or sparse matrix with rows are documents and columns are features
  • feature_names – An optional list of feature names (for sparse matrices)
  • k – Number of dimensions to extract
Returns:

A tuple of two dataframes, (features x components, documents x components)

Inter-rater Reliability¶

pewanalytics.stats.irr.kappa_sample_size_CI(kappa0, kappaL, props, kappaU=None, alpha=0.05)[source]¶

Translated from kappaSize: https://github.com/cran/kappaSize/blob/master/R/CIBinary.R :param kappa0: The preliminary value of kappa :param kappaL: The desired expected lower bound for a two-sided 100(1 - alpha) % confidence interval for kappa. Alternatively, if kappaU is set to NA, the procedure produces the number of required subjects for a one-sided confidence interval :param props: The anticipated prevalence of the desired trait :param kappaU: The desired expected upper confidence limit for kappa :param alpha: The desired type I error rate :return:

pewanalytics.stats.irr.kappa_sample_size_power(rate1, rate2, k1, k0, alpha=0.05, power=0.8, twosided=False)[source]¶

Translated from N.cohen.kappa: https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/irr/irr.pdf :param rate1: the probability that the first rater will record a positive diagnosis :param rate2: the probability that the second rater will record a positive diagnosis :param k1: the true Cohen’s Kappa statistic :param k0: the value of kappa under the null hypothesis :param alpha: type I error of test :param power: the desired power to detect the difference between true kappa and hypothetical kappa :param twosided: TRUE if test is two-sided :return: returns required sample size

Mutual Information¶

pewanalytics.stats.mutual_info.compute_mutual_info(y, x, weights=None, col_names=None, l=0, normalize=True, sort_by='MI', top_n=40, return_raw=False)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • y – An array or, preferably, a pandas.Series
  • x – A matrix, pandas.DataFrame, or preferably a Scipy csr_matrix
  • col_names – The feature names associated with the columns in matrix ‘x’
  • l – An optional Laplace smoothing parameter
  • normalize – Toggle normalization on or off (to control for feature prevalance), on by default
  • top_n – The number of features for each partition you want to return
Returns:
